headline.main: A Doctor Who Must Navigate a Contentious Divide

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Jonathan Samet, chairman of World Health Organization committee that found cellphones to be 'possibly carcinogenic'; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: After years of weighing in on issues like secondhand tobacco smoke and radon exposure, Dr. Jonathan Samet is accustomed to controversy. And last week, Dr. Samet, a University of Southern California physician and epidemiologist, found himself at the center of debate again as chairman of a World Health Organization committee ruling on the health effects of cellphone use. The International Agency for Research on Cancer, which consisted of 31 scientists from 14 countries, concluded that cellphones are ''possibly carcinogenic,'' putting the devices in the same category as about 260 chemicals, pesticides and other substances, including coffee, that might lead to certain cancers.

headline.main: A Doctor Who Must Navigate a Contentious Divide

docs.abstract: An international agency’s finding that cellphones are “possibly carcinogenic” has put Dr. Jonathan Samet in the middle of a scientific debate.
docs.lead_paragraph: After years of weighing in on issues like secondhand tobacco smoke and radon exposure, Dr. Jonathan Samet is accustomed to controversy.
